LOAN, GRANT, AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: Targeted intervention (TI-M) 
Sector: Water supply, sanitation, and waste management 
Subsector: Water supply and sanitation 
Themes: Inclusive social development, environmental 
sustainability, capacity development 
Subthemes: Human development, urban environmental 
improvement, institutional development 
   
Environment and Social  The  Project  is  classified  as  environment  category  B.  Initial 
Safeguards Assessment  environmental examinations and an environmental management 
plan were prepared. 
 
The  Project  is  classified  as  category  B  for  involuntary 
resettlement. Four resettlement plans were prepared. 
   
Rationale   Sri Lanka’s northern dry zone receives little rainfall, mostly within 
the short winter monsoon. Residents of the region experience 
income and nonincome poverty. For decades, major towns have 
accommodated  those  displaced  by  the  civil  war.  Water  is 
therefore essential to improve the lives of residents of this region 
and those affected by years of conflict. 
 
Water schemes in major towns have been stretched beyond their 
design life and have substantial inefficiencies; coverage is limited 
to a reduced number of beneficiaries; and standards are often not 
met, which could impact the health of those served. Where piped 
drinking  water  is  not  available,  water  is  extracted  from  other 
sources; however quality is often poor and seldom verified. In 
addition to limited access, water supplies are usually insufficient, 
particularly at the end of the dry season. Demand and willingness 
to pay for water and sanitation are nonetheless high, particularly 
in  Mannar,  Puttalam,  and  Vavuniya.  As  water  supply 
augmentation  is  considered  in  emerging  regional  centers, 
wastewater and septage management must be addressed as an 
integral part of the solution. 
 
The problem analysis reveals that (i) access to basic facilities and 
services, including water supply and sanitation, is restricted; and 
existing infrastructure is inadequate, insufficient, and/or damaged; 
(ii)  water  resource  coordination  and  planning  are  weak,  and 
essential  policies  for  water  resource  management  are  lacking; 
(iii) operation and maintenance of existing assets is suboptimal; 
and (iv) institutional capacity is poor, and awareness among users 
and beneficiaries is inadequate.

ii   
Project Description  The Project has three principal thrusts to support research and 
data  collection,  institutional  development,  and  infrastructure 
investment. It comprises three components: Component 1 covers 
the  rehabilitation,  expansion,  and  development  of  water  and 
sanitation infrastructure for major towns in the northwestern dry 
zone (Chilaw, Mannar, Puttalam, and Vavuniya), including urban 
and  periurban  water  supply,  and  septage  management  and 
sanitation. Component 2 provides the foundations to (i) support 
decentralization of service delivery functions to regional offices; 
(ii)  improve  water  resource  management,  coordination,  and 
planning ability; and (iii) increase public awareness. Component 3 
is  designed  to  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  project 
management and implementation activities. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected impact of the Project is improved physical well-
being of urban populations in Sri Lanka’s northwestern dry zone. 
The expected outcome is improved urban water and sanitation 
services and management in Sri Lanka’s urban northwestern dry 
zone. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $113.3 million, 
including taxes and duties of $15.3 million.  
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $59,780,000 equivalent and a grant of $23,220,000 from 
the  Special  Funds  resources  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) will be provided to finance the Project. Financing charges 
will be 1% per year during the grace period and 1.5% during the 
amortization  period  for  the  Asian  Development  Fund  loan.  In 
addition, a $2,000,000 grant from the Netherlands Trust Fund, 
administered by ADB, for the Water Financing Partnership Facility 
will help finance the Project.

iii
Allocation and Relending  The Government will pass on the loan proceeds to the National 
Terms  Water  Supply  and  Drainage  Board  (NWSDB)  as  a  blend  of 
Government grant and Government loan. The ratio of Government 
grant and loan is based on urban and rural population ratios in the 
project areas. Lending arrangements between the Government 
and NWSDB are as follows: funding for water supply schemes in 
areas  under  the  pradeshiya  sabhas  will  be  made  available  to 
NWSDB as a 85% grant and 15% a loan; funding for water supply 
in areas under the municipal and urban councils will be 50% grant 
and 50% loan; and financing for septage treatment schemes will 
be provided as a 100% grant. In each case, Government loan 
financing will be at the rate of 10% per annum with a repayment 
period of 25 years and grace period of 5 years.

Implementation  NWSDB  will  implement  most  of  the  activities.  Central  and 
Arrangements  provincial  irrigation  departments  will  be  responsible  for 
implementation of rehabilitation and improvement works for the 
Elawankulama and Achchamolai reservoirs, and construction of a 
new small reservoir on Per Aru. NWSDB, in close coordination 
with urban councils in project towns, will implement the sanitation 
improvement subcomponent. A small project coordination cell will 
be established within NWSDB’s head office; the cell will have 
monitoring,  coordination,  and  supervisory  roles.  The  bulk  of 
activities will be implemented by existing NWSDB regional offices 
that will be duly strengthened. Vavuniya regional office will be 
responsible for water supply and sanitation development works in 
Vavuniya and Mannar. Puttalam regional office will be responsible 
for water supply and sanitation development works in Puttalam 
and Chilaw. 
   
Procurement  NWSDB’s regional offices will carry out most of the procurement; 
while central and provincial irrigation departments, supported by 
the project implementation consultants, will take responsibility for 
procurement  activities  relating  to  tank  rehabilitation  and 
construction. Procurement of water supply and septage schemes 
will follow procedures for international and national competitive 
bidding.  Goods  and  related  services,  and  civil  works  to  be 
financed from loan proceeds will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time).

iv   
  Civil  works  contracts  valued  over  $3.0  million  equivalent  and 
equipment  contracts  valued  over  $500,000  equivalent  will  be 
undertaken through international competitive bidding procedures, 
while civil works contracts valued at $3.0 million equivalent or less 
and equipment packages valued at $500,000 equivalent or less 
will be procured following national competitive bidding procedures 
acceptable to ADB. Packages valued at $100,000 equivalent or 
less will be under shopping procedures. 
   
Consulting Services  An estimated 871 person-months (86 international, 785 national) 
of  consulting  services  are  needed.  Consulting  services  are 
required to (i) facilitate project implementation and management; 
and  (ii)  strengthen  institutional,  administrative,  and  financial 
capacities of the regional offices. NWSDB will recruit two firms, in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). This includes (i) package 
A,  for  design  and  construction  supervision  support;  and 
(ii)  package  B,  for  institutional  development.  Package  A  will 
include  60  person-months  of  international  expertise  and  588 
person-months of national. In addition, about 788 person-months 
of technical and support staff will be provided under package A for 
project implementation. Package B will include 11 person-months 
of international expertise and 79 person-months of national; while 
package  C,  for  water  resource  management,  will  include  15 
person-months of international expertise and 118 person-months 
of national. The consulting firms will be engaged using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method with a standard quality-cost ratio 
of 80:20. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will directly benefit approximately 200,000 people (at 
Beneficiaries  project  completion,  420,000  by  2030)  in  urban  areas  of  the 
northwestern  dry  zone  by  providing  safe  drinking  water  and 
improved sanitation. In addition, around 100,000 will gain access 
to  improved  sanitation;  pit  desludging;  and  septage  handling, 
treatment,  and  disposal.  More  than  400,000  will  benefit  from 
improved water management and distribution, as well as improved 
ecology.  Increasing  access  to  safe  water,  and  improving 
sanitation will impact poverty reduction through improved public 
health resulting in reduced expenditures on medical expenses and 
reduced work days lost from sickness, and consequent increase 
in  labor  productivity  and  income.  Time  savings  from  water 
collection,  particularly  for  women  and  children,  will  result  in 
increased  time  for  productive  activities  and  improved  human 
capital. Providing safe water supply will reduce productive time 
spent by women on water collection and release them from the 
tension  and  uncertainty  attached  to  depending  on  unreliable 
sources of water.

v
Risks and Assumptions  The Project assumes (i) a stable political environment and positive 
economic  growth,  particularly  in  Vavuniya  and  Mannar;  and 
(ii)  commitment  by  all  institutions  to  actively  participate  in  the 
planning and development process. Specific monitoring measures 
are in place to mitigate this risk. NWSDB will brief ADB on the 
progress of each of the packages, immediately highlighting any 
disruption  associated  with  security  matters.  The  Project  will 
implement  the  following  mitigation  measures:  (i)  careful  and 
continuous  monitoring  of  security  developments;  (ii)  preferred 
recruitment of district-based qualified staff; (iii) continued dialogue 
with stakeholders and aid partners; (iv) complete participatory and 
transparent  implementation,  including  disclosure  of  financial 
information; (v) mobilization of strong community support and trust 
in project staff; and (vi) encouragement of local employment.   
 
The Government is expected to revise water tariffs on a timely 
basis  to  meet  existing  cost-recovery  objectives  and  related 
financial considerations, and be independent of political influence. 
 
To  mitigate  deviations  from  existing  population  and  demand 
projections, the overall water supply strategy for Vavuniya and 
Puttalam is phased. The Project will provide resources to finance 
the  first  stage.  Phasing  will  build  confidence  among  farmers. 
Extensive consultations, initiated under the feasibility study, will be 
continued  during  implementation,  ensuring  that  information  is 
conveyed and farmers’ concerns are timely addressed.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan,  (ii)  a  proposed  grant,  and  (iii)  proposed  administration  by  ADB  of  a  grant  from  the 
Netherlands Trust Fund for the Water Financing Partnership Facility to the Democratic Socialist 
Republic of Sri Lanka, for the Dry Zone Urban Water and Sanitation Project. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Country Performance. Strong economic growth over the past decade has resulted in 
improving development indicators in Sri Lanka.1 Income poverty, as measured by the headcount 
ratio,  declined  slowly  from  26.1%  in  1990  to  22.7%  in  2002;  however  income  inequality 
increased. A recent study2 indicates that based on expenditure, the poverty headcount in 2007 
was 15.2%. In 2004, life expectancy was 74.3 years, adult literacy 90.7%, and gross domestic 
product per capita $1,031. The population with sustainable access to an improved water source 
is reported to have increased from 67% to 74%, between 1990 and 2005, whereas the fraction 
with access to improved sanitation increased from 61% to 68% over the same period.3 Major 
challenges  include  regional  disparities  and  urban–rural  differences.  These  have  been 
accompanied by marked demographic changes relating to migration within the country and 
abroad.4 Medium-term prospects hinge on Government plans to foster economic growth by 
significantly raising foreign direct investment as well as domestic public and private investment. 
Large infrastructure developments have been limited in recent years, resulting in economic 
bottlenecks. Development of secondary cities into strong regional centers capable of adequately 
serving  district  populations  and  operating  as  growth  engines  requires  special  attention, 
particularly in more disadvantaged areas such as the northwestern and southeastern parts of 
the country. While the southeastern region has received extensive support in recent years, this 
needs to be extend to districts in the western and northern regions, in particular Mannar, 
Puttalam and Vavuniya. In addition to strategic development, the choice of project districts and 
towns aims to address the dual hardship encountered in this region: (i) difficulties (economic 
and others) associated with living in an arid environment, and (ii) the critical role played in 
accommodating internally displaced populations, many of which have settled over time. 
 
3.  The Dry Zone. Sri Lanka's climate can be generally described as tropical and hot. Most 
of the southeast, east, and northern parts of the country comprise the dry zone, which receives 
little rainfall concentrated during the short winter monsoon. Economic activity in this region is 
generally linked to the nature of this ecological zone. A large proportion of the active labor force 
is employed in agriculture; livestock farming; fisheries; and, in urban areas, in the Government 
sectors. Economic development in major urban settlements in the region has been heavily 
influenced by the country’s general economic growth and ability to maintain peace.5 Population 
migration and movement remains complex, but in general all towns, and in particular Vavuniya, 
Mannar,  and  Puttalam  have  played  a  critical  role  in  accommodating  internally  displaced

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
4.  A  problem  and  constraints  analysis  is  in  Appendix  2,  an  analysis  of  the  sector  in 
Appendix 3, and a chronology of preparatory activities is in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
5.  Water Resource Management. Sri Lanka’s dry zone is generally characterized by low 
precipitation. The arid northwest and southeast coasts receive the least amount of rain: 600–
1,200  mm  per  year.  Water  resources,  whether  in  the  form  of  (mostly  perennial)  rivers  or 
groundwater, are scarce. Vavuniya district dotted landscape, the only one of the three districts 
not in the northwestern coastal belt, is characterized by a multitude of water tanks (often 
cascading), constructed since ancient times to capture perennial waters from the catchments. 
This pattern, although less discernible, has been extensively used in inland areas of Mannar 
and Puttalam districts. However the reservoirs are often in poor state, breached, or utilized at 
suboptimal levels. Multiple uncoordinated competing uses and users operating in isolation have 
exacerbated the situation. The use of groundwater resources has intensified, as reflected in a 
significant increase in water pumps and agrowells.10 The aquifer is fragile and at risk; the 
situation is deteriorating as uncontrolled extraction intensifies.11    
 
6.  Increasing overextraction of groundwater, resulting from population and development 
pressures, and the use of water resources for multiple competing uses has led to fast depletion 
of the aquifer and salinity intrusion. To ensure efficient, equitable, and sustainable water use 
and to reduce poverty and improve well-being of the community, irrigation and water resource 
policies need to consider all uses and users within a water system. 12 Policies and development 
strategies  need  to  consider  long-term  impacts  of  water as  a shared  resource.  Addressing 
threats to the water resource base in the dry zone requires an integrated, cross-sectoral, and 
multidisciplinary institutional framework that operates regionally and locally. Countrywide, the

7.  Water  Infrastructure:  Coverage  and  Service.  The  National  Water  Supply  and 
Drainage Board (NWSDB) operates urban water supply schemes in all major towns in the 
northern dry zone region. In all instances, schemes have been stretched beyond their design life 
resulting  in  operating  deficiencies.  Investment  for  improvement  and  expansion  is  urgently 
needed. Coverage is limited to a reduced number of beneficiaries,16 the schemes run at a small 
fraction of their design capacity,17 nonrevenue water (NRW) is significant18 and service does not 
meet required standards. In Vavuniya and Mannar, water is supplied daily for an average of  
2–3 hours; in Puttalam, supply is on a zonal basis for an average of 6 hours; while in Chilaw the 
average is 4-5 hours.19 All of the schemes, except for Mannar, are subject to water quality 
constraints  arising  from  high  iron,  manganese,  salinity,  and  pH  (Puttalam,  Chilaw),  and 
hardness (Vavuniya) in groundwater.  
 
8.  Where piped drinking water is not available, water is generally sourced from private or 
public dug or tube wells, public tanks, ponds, and channels;20 however the quality of extracted 
water is often compromised and seldom verified. In addition to limited access, water supplies 
are usually insufficient, particularly at the end of the dry season. Demand and willingness to pay 
for water and sanitation are nonetheless high, particularly in Vavuniya, Mannar, and Puttlam. 
Total  water  demand  in  target  towns  in  2030  (including  supply  for  domestic,  institutional, 
commercial, and industrial purposes) is estimated at around 87,000 cubic meters per day, for a 
projected  population  of  about  420,000.  Potential  new  groundwater  sources  have  been 
investigated for the four towns, but currently only the Murunkan subbasin is considered to be 
able to sustainably provide supplementary drinking water to Mannar. To fulfill current and future 
demand, surface water will be used to supplement existing sources.21

9.  Integrated Water and Sanitation. Conventional piped sewerage has been constructed 
in only a few areas of Sri Lanka.22 The majority of households in the project area dispose of 
their wastewater through a combined system consisting of (i) common sanitation technology, 
typically pour-flush toilets connected to either a septic tank (larger or institutional buildings) or 
directly into a soakage pit (most households),23 and (ii) a crisscross of storm-water drains often 
utilized in most densely populated areas to discharge grey and kitchen water. Groundwater 
resources, particularly around densely populated areas, are at risk of bacterial contamination24 
caused by effluent leakage and pollutant migration from poorly maintained pit latrines, septic 
tanks, and other disposal facilities.25 As water supply augmentation is considered in emerging 
regional centers, wastewater and septage management must be addressed as part of the 
solution. Based on appropriate technology, affordability and financial viability, and health and 
environmental principles, solutions have been found to match the needs of the various centers. 
Sanitation also involves changing attitudes and behavior (especially hygiene habits), developing 
solutions, and creating a demand for sanitation to ensure that systems are effective. 
 
10.  Sector Performance (Appendix 3). Laws relating to the distribution and use of water in 
Sri Lanka are largely based on water rights rather than ownership of the water resource base. 
Although  water  supply  and  sanitation  policies  have  been  drafted,  their  approval  remains 
pending. Main problems faced by the sector in the delivery of water and sanitation are low self-
financing ratios, insufficient tariff recovery, and high production costs. NWSDB, consistent with 
its corporate strategy,26 is focusing efforts on improving its operating and financial performance. 
Specific actions include the development of a new tariff methodology to meet revised cost-
recovery objectives, recent introduction of a sewerage tariff, and quarterly monitoring of financial 
indicators. In parallel, progress has been achieved by programs to reduce power consumption 
and strengthen financial management, but performance in the area of reducing nonrevenue 
water remains inadequate and generally underfunded. Moreover, in recent years, NWSDB has 
initiated several policy reforms aimed at improving institutional efficiency and decentralizing 
planning and management. NWSDB’s vision, as formulated in its corporate plan, specifically 
proposes (i) decentralizing financial and administrative authority in a first stage, to be followed 
by additional responsibilities; and (ii) transforming regional support centers 27 into small business

capacity  of  regional  support  centers  and  regional  offices  to  provide  more  efficient  and

  1.  Poverty Reduction and Social Development  
46.  The socioeconomic survey of 2,837 households conducted during project preparation 
shows high income poverty consistent with Government statistics.49 The project towns have 
acute shortages of drinking water and sanitation. The survey shows that only 14% in Vavuniya, 
50% in Chilaw, 58% in Puttalam, and 62% in Mannar have access to piped water, and it is not 
available 24 hours a day. Access is lower for poor households, with the number not having 
water  connections  at  36%  in  Vavuniya,  30.8%  in  Chilaw,  16.3%  in  Mannar,  and  9.9%  in 
Puttalam. During the dry season, the majority spend up to 50 minutes each day fetching water. 
Both piped and well water suffer from poor quality, with color as the most often cited problem. 
The substantial time for fetching could be used for productive activities. Access to sanitation 
ranges from 78% to 91% in project towns. Through the provision of water supply and sanitation, 
the Project contributes directly to poverty reduction through achievement of the Millennium 
Development  Goal  target  7;  and  indirectly  by  reducing  regional  disparities  in  urban 
infrastructure,  which  is  expected  to  impact  economic  growth  and  consequently  poverty 
reduction. The Project has specific design elements that directly target poor beneficiaries such 
as providing community connections to serve internally displaced people’s camps and poorer 
urban dwellers (to be maintained by community-based organizations and low-cost sanitation 
program for poor communities in the form of individual household latrines in newly served areas. 
Sex-disaggregated data will be collected as part of the baseline surveys. The summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 11.

sanitation.  According  to  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme,  in  2004  the  country 
achieved 79% coverage of improved water supply.1 While recent reports indicate that Sri Lanka 
is expected to meet the Millennium Development Goal target 7 by 2015, major challenges faced 
include regional disparities and urban–rural differences. Statistics show that urban population 
with access to improved water sources increased from 91% to 98% between 1990 and 2004; 
whereas in rural areas, population served increased from 62% to 74%. While 75% of the urban 
population is served with piped water, only 14% of the rural population benefits from such 
service, mostly (65%) relying on water obtained through protected wells. Differences between 
provinces are even more prominent and conditions in the north and east, particularly in areas 
affected  by  protracted  conflict  and  civil  war,  are  not  fully  reflected  in  aggregate  statistics.2 
According to the same sources, about 91% of the population in Western Province had access to 
safe drinking water, with the Colombo district recording the highest access at 96%; whereas the 
proportion of households in northern districts with access to improved water supply in 2001 was 
reported to be only 21.2% in Mannar and 67.8% in Vavuniya. The World Bank reports that only 
46% of the population in north and east has access to safe drinking water.3  
 
2.  Considerable improvements have been achieved in sanitation: urban population with 
access  to  improved  sanitation  increased  from  89%  to  98%  between  1990  and  2004,  rural 
coverage rose from 64% to 89%.4 Comparing access to improved sanitation across districts in 
Sri Lanka, the highest access is recorded in Colombo (96.2%) and Gampaha (96.5%), and the 
lowest in Batticaloa (57%) in the east. However, caution must be observed as data available for 
the north and east are sometimes incomplete and less reliable.5 Provision of sewerage services 
in  Sri  Lanka  is  limited  to  some  areas  of  Greater  Colombo6 and  Hikkaduwa.  However,  the 
Government is conscious of this growing problem and proposes expansion to other urban areas 
for Kandy and Jaffna. 
 
3.  Prolonged conflict and low productivity in rural areas have had a severe impact on urban 
centers. On average, the urban population (currently representing 27% of the national total) is 
growing nearly twice as fast as the rural population. Urbanization is projected to reach 45% by 
2015. Regional disparities in the quality and level of public infrastructure services are significant. 
With  limited  infrastructure  and  services,  old  and  new  urban  centers  are  not  capable  of 
adequately supporting the increasing economic productivity of households. The country’s urban 
areas exhibit problems such as slum and squatter settlements, degraded environment, low

B.  Government Targets 
4.  In  support  of  its  poverty  reduction  efforts  and  commitments  to  the  United  Nations 
Millennium Declaration, the Government identifies access to safe drinking water and adequate 
sanitation as priority objectives. Specific goals8 include (i) provision of sufficient and safe drinking 
water to 85% of the population by 2015 and 100% by 2025, (ii) provision of piped water supply to 
100% of the urban population and 75% of the total rural population by 2010, (iii) service levels 
and quality of water to achieve national standards in urban and rural areas, (iv) access to 
adequate sanitation to 70% of the population of Sri Lanka by 2010 and 100% by 2025, (v) piped 
sewerage  systems  to  be  provided  in  major  urban  areas  and  selected  growth  centers,  and  
(vi) standard on-site sanitation to be available to all those not connected to a sewerage system 
or sanitation scheme. 
 
5.  The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) Corporate Plan (2007–2011)9 
aims to provide 40% of Sri Lanka’s population with water supply services and 3% with piped 
sewerage coverage during implementation of the plan. Growth centers are to be identified where 
piped schemes are technically and economically viable, and coverage increased where existing 
schemes can be rehabilitated and augmented. Piped sewerage in 2006 is reported to have 
served 479,922 people or 2.4% of the population. Rehabilitation and partial augmentation of 
Greater Colombo’s sewerage scheme will substantially contribute to achieving this target. 
 
C.  Policy and Institutions 
6.  Institutional Mandates for Water and Sanitation (Service Delivery). The Ministry of 
Water  Supply  and  Drainage  is  the  lead  agency  in  the  water  supply  and  sanitation  sector, 
however the Ministry of Urban Development and Sacred Areas has a number of competencies 
relating to rural water and sanitation. The Ministry of Water Supply and Drainage is the policy 
making body in Sri Lanka for the development and improvement of water supply and sanitation. 
All  major  government  water  supply  and  sanitation  projects,  particularly  in  urban  areas,  are 
centralized at the Ministry of Water Supply and Drainage and the ministry is often tasked as the 
executing agency for foreign-funded projects. While the National Water Supply and Drainage 
Board  (NWSDB),  under  the  Ministry  of  Water  Supply  and  Drainage,  is  mandated  with 
implementing  water  development  projects  in  urban  and  rural  areas,  the  Ministry  of  Urban 
Development and Sacred Areas (through the Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Division) is 
actively involved in rural areas. NWSDB is involved in the supply of piped water and sewerage 
services, however relevant laws also provide powers and responsibilities to municipal and urban 
councils and pradeshiya sabhas to establish and maintain schemes for their constituency. On a 
smaller scale, some nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and community-based organizations 
are actively involved in providing services.

10.  Water Resource Management. In Sri Lanka, inefficient use of water resources has been 
exacerbated by the fact that a variety of agencies have exploited the resource, each pursuing its 
own mandate, with no single agency having stewardship over the country’s water resources per 
se. In the past, studies11 identified up to 28 agencies in 10 ministries responsible for one or more 
aspects of water resource management.12 This multiplicity of agencies operating in the water 
management sector, more or less independently of each other, continues to result in distortions 
and inefficiencies. This includes (i) large water users allocating water to themselves, assuming 
both the roles of regulator and user, potentially allocating water in an impartial manner; (ii) water 
required for environmental and social needs may not be protected since these uses are not 
recognized in policy and no mechanisms exist to legally safeguard minimum in-stream flows or 
reservoir levels; (iii) the supply of water for existing uses is vulnerable where new water use 
continues  to  be  allowed—this  lack  of  control  of  water  demand  increases  the  risk  of  water 
shortages and reduces the value of downstream water-related investment; (iv) water allocation is 
not flexible, therefore new users cannot be supplied by voluntary transfer of water from existing 
users—thus existing users have no incentive to improve efficiency of water use and recognize 
the value of their allocation; and (v) no planning system is in place to allocate water to priority 
uses.

D.  NWSDB Performance and Targets 
12.  Planning and Asset Management. NWSDB’s current corporate plan does not present a 
solid business plan with financial projections that translate action plans into financial terms, and 
key performance and result areas into financial targets or indicators that can be monitored. The 
annual budget is prepared over 5 months using the performance-based budgeting method, 
where costs and inputs are planned to match performance and outputs. Historically, operation 
investment-related functions have been more closely based on a crisis-management approach 
than through strategic decisions considering risk analyses and the long-term future sustainability 
of a network, or a holistic approach considering all influences upon the options available whether 
they  are  legal,  technical,  financial,  regulatory,  operations,  or  customer  service  driven.13 Yet 
NWSDB has acknowledged that revisions to its operating approach must be introduced. It is in 
the process of introducing, among others, a program to decentralize responsibilities to regional 
offices.14 This, if adequately strengthened, is expected to lead to rapid and responsive decision 
making.

8.  Key environmental performance objectives for on-site facilities are (i) wastewater will not 
cause topsoil contamination, (ii) surface water will not be polluted, (iii) groundwater will not be 
polluted, (iv) discharge will not upset the ecological balance, (v) waste should not be accessible

compliance with groundwater pollution requirements remains a problem. More care needs to be

existing  regulatory  framework,  local  authorities  will  need  to  introduce  a  program  of 
environmental monitoring activities on (i) quality of discharge to sea, if any; and (ii) quality of 
treated septage.  
 
C.  Integrated Water Resource Management 
10.  Although Sri Lanka’s total water supplies are abundant compared with those in other arid 
countries, water stress is now being experienced, and regional and seasonal variations in 
supply and demand create concerns. Existing urban water supply systems in project towns 
suffer  from  chronic,  and  occasionally  acute,  water  shortage;  and  delays  in  new  domestic 
connections are linked to uncertainty in water availability. The Project has considered these 
aspects and incorporated integrated water resource management concepts in its design through 
(i) securing comprehensive investigations (including 1-year quality and yield data) for surface 
and groundwater schemes, (ii) developing catchment protection plans, and (iii) developing local 
capacity and databases to monitor groundwater usage and depletion. The Project is phasing 
construction to facilitate monitoring of any upstream and downstream impacts. 
 
D.  Improved Financial Management 
11.  While  improvement  of  the  system’s  performance,  coupled  with  a  higher  rate  of 
connections, will help improve the finances of NWSDB, great emphasis is being placed on 
securing compliance with NWSDB’s owned defined objectives (footnote 1): (i) increase tariffs 
annually by at least inflation, (ii) ensure tariffs are sufficient to prevent any national losses 
(generating a small profit), and (iii) ensure tariffs are sufficient to cover at least O&M of all 
schemes. NWSDB and the Ministry of Water Supply and Drainage have agreed to submit the 
tariff methodology for approval by Cabinet before the date set for loan negotiations. All local 
septage schemes must cover no less than O&M costs. This is to be secured through the 
introduction of necessary bylaws (prior to contract award). 
 
E.  Urban Planning  
12.  The design of project schemes is based on development patterns envisaged under plans 
prepared by the respective urban development authorities. These have been discussed with 
urban councils and, given the nature and large floating populations present in most of the 
project towns, designs have accommodated the necessary flexibility.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.   Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  Project  will  improve  water  supply  service  delivery  and  expand  services  to  underserved  areas  in  four  towns  in 
disadvantaged districts of Sri Lanka. The project towns are in poor districts with poverty incidence at 31.3% for Chilaw, 42.5% 
for Mannar, 45.9% for Puttalam, and 27.5% for Vavuniya. The Project will provide low-cost sanitation and septage or sewage 
treatment in the four towns. 
 
The Project will directly support social and environmental development for the poor as specified in the nationalized Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs), specifically target 7, which aims to halve the proportion of people without sustainable access to 
drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015. This contributes to the National Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy 
(NPRGS, 2004) which aims to mainstream long-term MDGs into the national development framework; and minimize regional 
variations in the incidence of poverty and narrow regional disparities in development. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention (TI-M) 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The NPRGS (2004) is a policy framework to steer pro-poor, pro-growth, and income redistribution strategies. Among its main 
objectives are minimizing regional variations in the incidence of poverty; narrowing regional disparities in development; and 
facilitating the mainstreaming of long-term MDGs into the national development framework. The MDGs for Sri Lanka (2005) 
identify access to water and sanitation as impeding poverty reduction; increasing access is a national priority. 
 
The Mahinda Chinthana: Vision for a New Sri Lanka, Development Framework 2006–2016 identifies that poverty is mainly 
confined to the districts in the north and east, and poor infrastructure is a factor causing higher poverty in these districts. In 
response, the document includes infrastructure and area-based poverty reduction programs for the development of the north 
and east. Improvement and expansion of infrastructure including water supply and sanitation, and urban infrastructure are 
identified as activities that will accelerate economic growth, resulting in poverty reduction.  
 
Through the provision of water supply and sanitation, the Project contributes directly to poverty reduction through the 
achievement of MDG target 7; and indirectly by reducing regional disparities in urban infrastructure, which is expected to 
impact economic growth and consequently poverty reduction.  
 
The Project targets full water supply coverage for populations in the project towns: approximately 200,000 people by project 
completion and 420,000 people by the end of the projected scheme’s life (2030). The Project will construct an estimated 
1,500 individual household latrines estimated to benefit 7,500 people; and septage and sewage treatment with an estimated 
200,000 beneficiaries. 
2. Design Features  
 
The Project supports the objective of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) of increasing overall access to 
improved water supply facilities in urban areas to 90% in 2009 and 100% in 2016. The Project will (i) improve service delivery, 
and (ii) expand services to underserved areas. Improvements in service delivery will focus on providing better quality water 
and lengthening water supply service duration to 24 hours, 7 days a week in all project towns at an adequate water pressure. 
The Project aims to provide full coverage for populations in the project area. For this purpose, NWSDB will (i) have provided 
within 1 year of project completion, connections to all households that have placed requests; and (ii) ensure that all 
standposts are converted to metered community connections with clearly identified users. Community connections, while 
limited, remain essential in the Project’s context, particularly those serving internally displaced people’s camps and poorer 
urban  dwellers.  Communities  supplied  with  water  through  communal  metered  facilities  will  form  community-based 
organizations (CBOs) that will register and sign an agreement with NWSDB. The CBOs will nominate representatives to 
coordinate and collect payments. 
 
The Project will provide funds to conduct a low-cost sanitation program for poor communities in the form of individual 
household latrines in periurban newly served areas. Priority will be given to lower income households and those that do not 
own or have access to basic latrines. It will aim to provide adequate cost-effective small-scale infrastructure. Nongovernment 
organizations will be engaged to support the Project and local government in mobilizing communities, delivering essential 
training, conducting a technical assessment, and evaluating initial capital investment for proposed schemes.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
A socioeconomic survey covering 2,837 households was conducted in the project area areas during project preparation. The 
results were verified and supplemented with focus group discussions. The survey covered household profile, income and 
expenditures, assets and control over resources, access to water and sanitation, access to sanitation and health, social 
capital, and environmental sanitation. 
 
The survey shows high income poverty in the project towns with poverty incidence at 28.9% for Chilaw, 37.5% for Mannar, 
39.7% for Puttalam, and 24.4% for Vavuniya. This is consistent with government statistics. The survey also shows high 
poverty gap ratios—2.06 in Chilaw, 2.79 in Mannar, 2.68 in Puttalam, and 1.7 in Vavuniya—and severity of poverty indices: 
0.82 in Chilaw, 1.31 in Mannar, 1.2 in Puttalam, and 0.75 in Vavuniya. Income inequality based on Gini coefficients are 0.360 
in Chilaw, 0.322 in Mannar, 0.282 in Puttalam, and 0.308 in Vavuniya. 
 
The survey also reflects relatively low education particularly in Mannar and Chilaw, where more than 30% of respondents 
have less than sixth-grade education. Unemployment is high at 56.8% in Chilaw, 36.6% in Mannar, and 60.5% in Puttalam. Of 
those employed, a high percentage are laborers or have low-income and seasonal jobs. 
 
The project towns have acute shortages of drinking water and sanitation. The survey shows that only 14% in Vavuniya, 50% 
in Chilaw, 58% in Puttalam, and 62% in Mannar have access to piped water. Piped water is not available for 24 hours a day in 
any of the towns. Access to safe drinking water is an even more serious issue for poor households. The number of poor 
households not having water connections is 36% in Vavuniya, 30.8% in Chilaw, 16.3% in Mannar, and 9.9% in Puttalam. 
Those without access to piped water often source their water from wells. During the dry season, the majority spend up to 
50 minutes each day fetching water. Both piped and well water are poor quality, with color the most often-cited problem. The 
substantial time for fetching could be used for potentially productive activities. Access to sanitation ranges from 78%–91% in 
project towns. Most is poor quality and with poor or no maintenance. Combined with wastewater polluting surrounding areas 
and health hazards from the poor urban environment, lack of safe water and adequate sanitation increases the incidence of 
water-borne disease.

1.  The  Project  aims  to  improve  urban  water  supply  and  sanitation  infrastructure  and

(iii)  where  Government  land  is  unavailable  due  to  constraints  (proximity  and  elevation

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION (SHORT) 
 
1.  The Dry Zone Urban Water and Sanitation Project will facilitate sustainable development 
in disadvantaged districts in Sri Lanka, by investing in priority water supply and sanitation 
infrastructure in urban areas in Chilaw, Mannar, , Puttalam, and Vavuniya. 
 
2.  The Project will be implemented over 5 years beginning in early 2009, supported by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a project loan and grant. The National Water Supply 
and  Drainage  Board  (NWSDB),  under  the  Ministry  of  Water  Supply  and  Drainage,  is  the 
Executing Agency. ADB classifies the Project as environmental assessment category B, as the 
Vavuniya water supply subproject includes one environmentally sensitive component (a 4 meter 
high dam and 215 hectare storage reservoir). The impacts of providing infrastructure were 
assessed by four initial environmental examination (IEE) reports (one for each location). An 
environmental  management  plan  for  the  storage  reservoir  in  Vavuniya  and  four  detailed 
environmental monitoring plans for the other less sensitive subcomponents in Vavuniya and 
subprojects in the other three towns were prepared. Studies were conducted according to ADB’s 
Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines  (2003).  NWSDB  will 
submit project information to the Central Environmental Authority (for Vavuniya and Mannar), 
and the North Western Provincial Environmental Authority (Puttalam and Chilaw), to initiate 
obtaining  the  necessary  environmental  clearances  required  by  Government  of  Sri  Lanka 
legislation. 
 
A.  Description of the Project 
3.  The proposed infrastructure varies in composition as each area has different needs, but 
improvements in a particular sector generally contain the same basic elements: 
 
(i)  Urban water supply: (a) source augmentation: increased abstraction of surface 
water or groundwater; (b) more efficient transfer: transmission main, pumping 
stations; (c) improved treatment: new or refurbished water treatment plant or 
increased chlorination; (d) increased storage: ground storage tanks, overhead 
reservoirs;  and  (e)  improved  or  extended  distribution:  distribution  main  and 
network. 
 
(ii)  Urban sanitation: (a) new pit latrines with septic tanks and soakage pits or only 
soakage pits in plots with space constraints; (b) improved emptying of septic 
tanks: new vacuum tanker vehicles; and (c) septage treatment: facility to dry 
sludge and treat liquid effluent.

infrastructure, and Table A13.2 summarizes the likely approach to construction of each element 
and operation of each scheme. All infrastructure will be designed during a 6-month detailed 
design stage in 2008, and built during a 4-year construction period (2009–2012).

Location  Chilaw, Puttalam, and Mannar are towns on the west coast of Sri Lanka; 70, 130, and 220

Topography,  The coastal towns and villages (Chilaw, Puttalam, and Mannar) are flat with sandy soils 
Soil, Geology  and are in a narrow Miocene to Quaternary belt of ferruginized gravels and alluvium over 
Miocene bedrock. Vavuniya is in the Precambrian Vanni complex of granitic gneiss and 
biotite that runs diagonally across the country. Soils here are mainly the more fertile 
reddish brown earth and the topography is gently undulating. 
Climate  Chilaw is in the intermediate rainfall zone with an average of 1,500–2,000 mm of rain per 
year. The other towns and villages are in the low rainfall zone and receive 500–1,500 mm 
per year only. About 40%–50% of the rain falls in October–November and 20%–30% 
during April–May. Temperatures reach daily averages of around 30°C in May–August and 
fall to around 25°C in December–January, dropping by around 5–10°C at night. Humidity 
is high, often >80%. 
Air Quality  Few data are available, but air quality is likely to be good because of the lack of heavy 
industry and dispersion by coastal winds. Particulate matter will increase during the dry 
season and soot may increase when vegetation is burned. 
Surface Water  Chilaw and Puttalam are in the drainage basins of the Dedru Oya and Kala Oya (rivers), 
which drain to the west coast; and Vavuniya is in the basin of the Malwatha Oya. Most 
areas have many tanks (large reservoirs built by constructing earth bunds across rivers or 
in low-lying areas), from where water flows into irrigation channels. Giant’s Tank near 
Mannar is the second largest in the country. 
Groundwater  Groundwater is contained in alluvial deposits and ferruginous gravels in Chilaw and 
Puttalam, and is exploited by private and public wells and by NWSDB to supply water to 
the towns. A large aquifer in Miocene limestone near Mannar is also exploited, and 
perched surface aquifers on the island. No data is available on the extent or yield of the 
aquifers or the quality of the water. Vavuniya has no major aquifers but some groundwater 
is present. 
Ecology  Vegetation has been removed from the inhabited areas and their surroundings to provide 
land for development and agriculture. Vegetation now consists of crops and fruit trees; 
animals are those able to live close to man. Irrigation tanks support aquatic plants and 
animals, and Chilaw and Puttalam lagoons are wetland habitats. Some riverine forest is 
along rivers, but the only protected area is Wilpattu National Park nexr to the Kala Oya. 
Land Use  Most  land  in  the  urban  areas  is  developed  for  housing,  shops,  small  industry,  and 
government offices; outside the land is mainly used for agriculture. In rural areas land is 
mainly used for housing and agriculture. 
Industry and  The only large industries are Holcim Cement and coastal salt pans at Puttalam, where a 
Agriculture  100 megawatt coal power plant is being built. Most other industry is small, including light 
engineering, garment manufacture, and brickworks. Farming is mainly paddy rice (irrigated 
and rain-fed) plus maize, vegetables, livestock. There are also coastal fisheries.  
Infrastructure  All target towns have a piped water supply based on groundwater, but water is only 
available for a few hours a day because of inefficient tuber wells and leaking networks. 
With no sewerage, people rely on septic tanks or pit latrines, and many households have 
no toilet. Open concrete drains run beside roads in towns, but most are blocked with silt 
and garbage. Solid waste is collected and dumped on land outside the towns as there are 
no landfills. Most people in towns and some in villages have electricity from the national 
grid. 
Transportation  All  towns  are  at  junctions  of  main  highways  and  have  good  road  connections  to 
neighboring towns and districts. Roads in the center of towns are generally congested. 
Public buses and motorcycles are the main transport. Chilaw, Puttalam, and Vavuniya are 
on the railway from Colombo, but at Mannar the track was destroyed some years ago by 
the LTTE (Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam). Villages are reached by unpaved roads from 
the nearest highway. 
Demography  With the exception of Chilaw, the towns are affected in varying degrees by the conflict 
between Government and the LTTE who wish to establish an autonomous Tamil state in 
the north. People (particularly Muslims) have moved from Mannar and other towns in the 
LTTE controlled area to safer areas in the south where many live in camps for internally 
displaced persons. The main religious and ethnic groups are Christian in Chilaw, Muslim

C.  Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
5.  Most of the minor negative impacts associated with the Project will be typical to those 
found in any construction project and could be mitigated by adopting good construction and 
operating practices. This section summarizes project-specific impacts, the generic impacts are 
discussed in detail in the four IEEs and the combined summary. 
 
6.  Main concerns related to the siting of septage treatment facilities are impacts due to odor 
and effluent discharge. Sites selected are away from communities, so nuisances from odor will 
be minimized. In two of the towns the treated effluent is proposed to be discharged to either 
coastal or lagoon waters. The users of such water may be concerned of (i) potential risks to 
health and livelihood, and (ii) impacts to receiving waters due to discharge of partially treated 
effluent resulting from system malfunctions. Although impacts are expected to be minimal, given 
the saline nature of the waters not conducive to commonly found bacteria, mitigation measures 
include (i) engaging users in the effluent discharge zone in consultations to explain the scheme; 
(ii) periodic monitoring of effluent and receiving water quality; and (iii) inclusion of emergency 
procedures in the operation and maintenance manuals, if discharge standards are exceeded. 
These will include (i) shutting off discharge and recycling the effluent, (ii) investigating reasons 
for failure and adopting remedial actions, and (iii) resuming discharge only when standards are 
met.  
 
7.  Although impacts related to design of water supply systems are expected to be minor, 
some uncertainties are still present at the stage of feasibility and additional data regarding the 
yield of the aquifer will be needed prior to finalizing detailed design. Therefore, at this stage, a 
program of borehole monitoring will be conducted to determine the extent, yield, and rate of 
recharge of the aquifer, groundwater quality, and quality of proposed surface water sources. 
This data will be used to (i) determine the location and sustainable extraction rates of the 
tubewells, (ii) redesign by selecting alternative water sources if proposed abstraction rates 
exceed sustainable yield, (iii) assess if proposed treatment and mixing will produce water of 
required quality, and (iv) redesign the treatment system if studies indicate more treatment is 
required. Additional water quality data is being collected for some proposed sources. In those

Appendix 13  59
schemes where treated surface water will be mixed with the groundwater, final quality of the 
water delivered to the end user will need to be tested to ensure that it meets drinking water 
standards.  
 
8.  The subproject warranting more attention is the construction of a 4 meter high, 1.5 km 
long earth bund across the Per Aru in Vavuniya to impound 3.7 million m3 of water in an area of 
215 hectares to provide a year-round supply. A fraction of the area is already used to store 
water. The Per Aru is a perennial relatively small stream and does not contain any important 
aquatic habitats or fisheries. Therefore the subproject will not have any significant ecological 
impacts. Presently, during monsoons, the Per Aru floods almost up to the proposed full supply 
level of the reservoir. Most of the vegetation, which includes secondary scrub and close cropped 
grass, will be removed from the drawdown area, to reduce generation of high concentrations of 
nitrate,  phosphate,  and  organic  matter  resulting  from  decomposing  organic  matter  in  the 
impounded waters. Small areas of primary riverine forests and around 38 hectares of paddy 
farming land will be inundated. Available information indicates that no water users are located 
downstream. Several studies including (i) the extent and species of primary riverine forest, (ii) 
detailed hydrogeological studies of flow rates in the river, (iii) verified ecological calculations of 
minimum  flow  required  to  maintain  existing  riverine  forest  downstream  and  to  support  an 
additional area equivalent to that lost upstream, and (iv) identification of suitable areas to be 
planted downstream and preparation of planting and maintenance plan for the new habitat, are 
proposed prior to initiating work on the reservoir. The new area of riverine forest will be planted 
before  the  reservoir  is  filled.  The  construction  of  the  reservoir  will  not  result  in  relocating 
communities, however, alternative land and/or compensation will be provided, for the loss of 38 
hectares of paddy farms, in line with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). One of the 
positive features of impounding surface water is that the aquifers in this area will recharge more 
readily from water that percolates to the ground from the bed of the reservoir. 
 
9.  Other than these impacts, construction of infrastructure is not expected to have major 
adverse impacts because 
(i)  most network improvements will be on unused ground alongside roads and can 
be  built  without  causing  major  disruption  to  road  users,  houses,  shops,  and 
businesses; 
(ii)  most  new  facilities  (overhead  reservoir,  PH,  WTP,  STF)  will  be  located  on 
government-owned land that is not occupied or used for any other purpose; 
(iii)  most network construction will be conducted by small teams working on short 
lengths at a time so most impacts will be localized and short in duration; and 
(iv)  the construction program will be relatively short for a project of this nature, and 
should be completed in 3–4 years in the towns. 
 
10.  The schemes should operate without major negative impacts because 
(i)  schemes are designed to use simple technologies with low maintenance and little 
replacement of parts to enhance their long-term sustainability; and 
(ii)  providing the responsible agency ensures that infrastructure is inspected regularly 
and maintained as required, repairs should be small-scale and short in duration. 
 
D.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Plan 
11.  Detailed  environmental  monitoring  plans  for  all  activities  in  the  four  towns  and  an 
environmental  management  plan  for  the  construction  of  the  reservoir  are  included  in  the 
individual IEEs. Environmental plans will be implemented and coordinated by an environment 
specialist attached to the project regional offices.

60   Appendix 13 
E.  Public Consultation and Information Disclosure 
12.  Primary stakeholders (residents, shopkeepers, and business people who live and work 
near the construction sites; and owners and users of any land that is acquired for the Project) 
and  secondary  stakeholders  (NWSDB,  other  relevant  government  institutions,  NGOs  and 
community-based  organizations  working  in  the  affected  communities;  other  community 
representatives) were consulted in developing the IEEs through face-to-face discussions on-site 
and large public meetings held in December 2007 and January 2008. Views and concerns were 
incorporated into the IEEs and the planning and development of the Project. The IEEs were 
made available in the local language at public locations in the towns and the summary initial 
environmental examination will be disclosed to a wider audience via the ADB website. NWSDB 
will appoint a nationally recognized NGO to handle consultation during project implementation to 
ensure full participation of stakeholders in subproject execution. 
 
F.  Findings and Recommendations 
13.  Environmental  issues  were  considered  throughout  development  of  the  Project  and 
necessary changes made to outline designs to reduce or avoid impacts. Mitigation measures for 
other impacts are provided in detail in the individual IEEs. Once the schemes are built, most 
should operate without major environmental impacts, providing the relevant agencies follow 
operation  and  maintenance  procedures  prepared  during  the  design  stage.  The  Project  will 
provide the agencies with training, and budgets to enable them to fulfill these responsibilities. 
 
14.  Some uncertainties relate to the impact analysis of operating some of the water supply 
schemes, and additional data will be collected to ensure sustainability and prevent any negative 
impacts. A range of studies (para. 7) will be conducted during the detailed design stage to 
ensure that abstraction is conducted only at sustainable amounts and that proposed treatment 
methods will deliver water meeting required standards. If the studies show that water cannot be 
abstracted  sustainably  by  methods  proposed,  subprojects  will  be  revised  accommodating 
alternative sources and/or treatment. Precautions are also needed at the septage treatment 
facilities, to protect the health of workers and the users of water into which treated effluent is 
discharged. Manuals and training will be provided for this purpose. 
 
15.  If water is abstracted sustainably and treated to the mandatory standards, then the 
citizens of the towns and villages should benefit substantially as they will be provided with a 
constant supply of good quality water and an improved sanitation service. Their quality of life 
should  therefore  improve  significantly.  The  Project  will  conduct  a  program  to  raise  public 
awareness of sanitation and hygiene issues so the health of the community should also improve. 
 
G.  Conclusions 
16.  The environmental impacts of the Project were assessed by the IEE studies summarized 
in this document, conducted according to ADB policy and procedures. Many impacts will be 
avoided by action during project development, and the IEEs describe further action that will be 
taken during detailed design, construction, and operation. 
 
17.  Most impacts identified by this analysis should be reduced to acceptable levels by the 
mitigation proposed. However final conclusions regarding the impacts of the schemes as a 
whole cannot be determined because of uncertainties regarding the impacts of operating the 
water supply components. This should be possible once the studies described in paragraphs 7 
and 8 are completed. The environmental monitoring plans and the environmental management 
plan will be updated during the detailed design stage.
